description: Pre-built reading group curricula with session plans

curricula.title: Foundations of Recursive Systems
curricula.description: An 8-week exploration of recursive, self-referential, and strange-loop systems — from formal logic through creative practice. Draws on foundational texts and ORGAN-I project artifacts to build intuition for how recursion generates novelty.

sessions.title: Strange Loops and Tangled Hierarchies
questions: What makes a loop 'strange' vs merely circular?
How does crossing levels of abstraction generate meaning?
Can you identify a strange loop in your own creative practice?
activities: Map a strange loop in a system you know well — draw the levels and the cross-level interaction

sessions.title: Self-Reference in Formal Systems
questions: How does Gödel's incompleteness theorem relate to creative systems?
What does the recursive-engine's generative entity model gain from self-reference?
Where does self-reference become pathological rather than productive?
activities: Write a 200-word description of your own work that references itself

sessions.title: Levels of Learning and Meta-Cognition
questions: What are Bateson's three levels of learning and why does Level III matter?
How does the cognitive-archaeology approach map to Bateson's levels?
What would it mean for a system to 'learn to learn to learn'?
activities: Identify one thing you learned this week, then identify what you learned about learning from that experience

sessions.title: Ontological Foundations
questions: What is the boundary between what can be formalized and what resists formalization?
How does the solve-coagula process relate to analysis and synthesis?
What does it mean for an ontology to be 'generative'?
activities: Decompose a concept you care about using the solve-coagula pattern: dissolve it into parts, then recombine in a new way

sessions.title: Autopoiesis and Self-Producing Systems
questions: What distinguishes an autopoietic system from a merely self-replicating one?
How do narratological algorithmic lenses treat narrative as self-producing?
Can a software system be genuinely autopoietic?
activities: Design a small system (on paper) that maintains its own boundary — what does it include and exclude?

sessions.title: Cybernetics and Feedback
questions: How do positive and negative feedback loops shape system behavior?
What role does feedback play in the organ system's governance model?
Where have you seen feedback loops create unexpected emergent behavior?
activities: Trace a feedback loop in the organvm system from ORGAN-I through to ORGAN-III and back

sessions.title: Recursive Art and Generative Practice
questions: How does recursion in art differ from recursion in mathematics?
What aesthetic qualities emerge from recursive processes that don't emerge from linear ones?
How does the ORGAN-I to ORGAN-II pipeline transform theory into art?
activities: Create something (text, image, sound, code) using a recursive process — share and discuss

sessions.title: Synthesis: Recursion as World-Making
questions: How does the eight-organ system itself embody recursive principles?
What does it mean to build a 'world' through recursive processes?
Where do you want to take recursive thinking next in your own practice?
activities: Write a one-page reflection on how your understanding of recursion has changed over these 8 weeks

curricula.title: Building in Public: The AI-Conductor Method
curricula.description: A 6-week study of transparent development methodology, drawing on ORGAN-V essays and external references. Examines the AI-conductor model, POSSE distribution, and the ethics of building with AI in public.

sessions.title: Why Build in Public?
questions: What are the risks and rewards of transparent development?
How does 'building in public' differ from open source?
What should remain private even in a public-first approach?
activities: Draft a one-paragraph public commitment for a project you're working on

sessions.title: The Conductor Model
questions: What distinguishes conducting from delegating?
How does the 80/20 principle (machine volume / human curation) actually work in practice?
What skills does an AI conductor need that a traditional developer doesn't?
activities: Conduct a small task using AI: define scope, set constraints, direct execution, curate output

sessions.title: Governance as Composition
questions: How does Conway's Law apply to AI-conducted systems?
What makes governance 'compositional' rather than 'restrictive'?
How do you balance structure with creative freedom?
activities: Write 3 governance rules for a hypothetical creative project — justify each one

sessions.title: Portfolio as Practice
questions: How does a portfolio tell a story that individual projects cannot?
What does a 5-year vision contribute to daily practice?
How do you curate your own work for public consumption?
activities: Organize 5 of your projects into a narrative arc — what story do they tell together?

sessions.title: Distribution and Reach
questions: What is POSSE and why does it matter for creative independence?
How does dependency integrity relate to content distribution?
What platforms should you own vs. syndicate to?
activities: Set up a POSSE workflow for one piece of content: publish on your own site, syndicate elsewhere

sessions.title: Ethics of AI-Conducted Creation
questions: When does AI-conducted work become misattribution?
How should credit work in conductor-model projects?
What are the environmental and social costs of high-volume AI creation?
How do you maintain authenticity at scale?
activities: Write your own attribution policy for AI-conducted work — what gets credited to whom and why?

curricula.title: From Theory to Product: The Organ Pipeline
curricula.description: A 10-week cross-organ journey tracing ideas from theoretical inception (ORGAN-I) through creative expression (ORGAN-II) to practical product (ORGAN-III), governed by ORGAN-IV and documented by ORGAN-V. The capstone curriculum of the koinonia reading group program.

sessions.title: The Eight-Organ Architecture
questions: Why eight organs and not five or twelve?
How does the organ metaphor shape what gets built?
What would you add or remove from this architecture?
activities: Draw your own version of a multi-organ creative system — what are your organs?

sessions.title: ORGAN-I: The Theoretical Root
questions: How does theory generate practice in the organvm model?
What makes a 'theoretical root' different from an 'idea'?
How do you cultivate theoretical foundations in your own work?
activities: Identify the theoretical root of a product you use daily — what ideas made it possible?

sessions.title: ORGAN-II: Theory Becomes Art
questions: What happens in the transition from theory to creative expression?
How does the metasystem-master architecture bridge abstract ideas and concrete artifacts?
When does creative interpretation become misinterpretation?
activities: Take a theoretical concept and express it in a non-theoretical medium — code, drawing, music, prose

sessions.title: ORGAN-III: Art Becomes Product
questions: What gets lost and what gets gained when creative work becomes a product?
How do user needs reshape artistic vision?
What makes a product 'ergonomic' in the organ-system sense?
activities: Identify a feature in a product that clearly came from an artistic or theoretical insight

sessions.title: ORGAN-IV: Governance as Enablement
questions: How does governance enable rather than constrain creativity?
What governance structures are present in open source projects you admire?
How do you govern your own creative process?
activities: Audit the governance of a project you contribute to — what rules exist, which are enforced, which are implicit?

sessions.title: ORGAN-V: Making the Process Visible
questions: Why does making the process visible change the process itself?
How does documentation serve as both record and creative act?
What are the limits of transparency?
activities: Document one hour of your creative process in real-time — what did you notice?

sessions.title: ORGAN-VI: Community as Infrastructure
questions: How does community infrastructure differ from social media?
What makes a salon different from a meeting?
How do reading groups create knowledge that individuals cannot?
activities: Design a salon session for a topic you care about — format, readings, questions, activities

sessions.title: ORGAN-VII: From Creation to Proclamation
questions: How does distribution shape what gets created?
What is the POSSE principle and why does it matter for creator independence?
How do you balance reach with authenticity?
activities: Map your current content distribution — where does your work go and who controls each channel?

sessions.title: Cross-Organ Dependencies
questions: How do dependencies between organs create both strength and fragility?
What happens when one organ fails or stalls?
How does the registry-v2 system track and validate these relationships?
activities: Draw a dependency map for a multi-component project you work on — identify the critical paths

sessions.title: Synthesis: Building Your Own System
questions: What would your own multi-organ creative system look like?
What has this curriculum changed about how you think about creative infrastructure?
Where do you go from here?
activities: Present a 5-minute pitch for your own creative system — what organs, what pipeline, what governance?
